key_insight: A spike-driven video transformer combines spiking neuron dynamics with temporal attention to deliver accurate surgical scene segmentation while greatly reducing compute and power needs, enabling real-time potential on resource-constrained systems.
problem_solved: Large, high-accuracy segmentation models are too computationally and energetically expensive for real-time use in operating rooms or edge surgical devices; this work targets accurate segmentation under strict latency and power budgets.
method: Design a video transformer that processes temporal frame streams using spike-based activations—reducing continuous floating-point operations and enabling event-like sparse computation.
Fuse temporal attention with spiking neuron layers to capture motion and scene context across frames while keeping the model lightweight and hardware-friendly.
Train with surrogate-gradient techniques and architecture optimizations to preserve segmentation accuracy comparable to conventional models while lowering latency and energy consumption.
impact: Enables practical deployment of high-quality surgical scene segmentation on edge and low-power devices, improving intra-operative situational awareness and safety. It also provides a pathway for AI practitioners to combine spiking networks with transformer-style temporal modeling for energy-efficient video tasks.

paper_title: Surgical Scene Segmentation using a Spike-Driven Video Transformer with Real-Time Potential
paper_authors: Shihao Zou, Jingjing Li, Wei Ji, Jincai Huang, Kai Wang
